title: Wyrley and Essington Canal Walking Route

images.title: John M / Wyrley and Essington Canal
images.caption: Wyrley and Essington Canal. Alongside Hawbush Road. The Curly Wyrley wanders around following the contours avoiding the need for locks.

images.title: Geoff Pick / Wyrley and Essington Canal
images.caption: Looking South West towards Bloxwich

images.title: John M / Wyrley & Essington Canal - Heath Town Bridge
images.caption: Heath Town Bridge. Neat modern canal bridge carrying Wednesfield Way.

images.title: Adrian Rothery / New Footbridge - Wyrley & Essington Canal
images.caption: New Footbridge

images.title: John M / Trapmakers Bridge - Wyrley & Essington Canal
images.caption:
Trapmakers Bridge - Wyrley & Essington Canal. The new footbridge awaits its official opening next week. The £2M scheme is intended to link the King George V Park to the village centre and replaces the former Barn Bridge demolished in the late 1950s. 914852 shows the site in 2006.
This looks to be another example of an expensive 'landmark' structure. The ramp only gives access to a muddy towpath requiring a walk up to the next bridge to meet the High Street or behind the library. The concrete block under the column on the far bank did not appear on the artist's impression but appears to have been a compromise during construction.
The relatively isolated location of the structure will make the bridge prone to vandalism and graffiti. This was already apparent even before its opening.

images.title: John M / Disused Lock on the Wyrley Branch - Wyrley & Essington Canal
images.caption: Disused Lock on the Wyrley Branch. The first lock above Sneyd Junction is the only one of the six locks to survive on the abandoned Wyrley Branch. Designed by James Brindley as a 'contour' canal the main line of the Curly Wyrley has no locks but takes a circuitous route.

images.title: John M / Pool on Pelsall Common North Nature Reserve
images.caption: Pool on Pelsall Common North Nature Reserve

images.title: John M / Pelsall Junction, Wyrley and Essington Canal
images.caption: Pelsall Junction, Wyrley and Essington Canal Junction with the disused Hatherton Branch Canal, Pelsall Common.

description: This walk takes you along the Wyrley and Essington Canal from Wolverhampton to the Rushall Canal in Walsall. The flat canalside trail is a great way of visiting some of the parks, nature reserves and historical sites of this area of the West Midlands. The canal is also known as the "Curly Wyrley" because of the way it twists and turns through the towns and cities. The walk starts in the centre of Wolverhampton, close to the train station. Follow the trail north east to Wednesfield and Rough Wood Country Park where you can explore the largest oak woodland in Walsall . You then head through Bloxwich, Harden, Pelsall Common , Clayhanger and Aldridge before finishing at the Rushall Canal. Here you could extend the walk by visiting Park Lime Pits which lies just to the west of the canal.
